case_name: K. Joseph Augusthi & Ors. v. Reserve Bank of India

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 254 to 256 of 1963 were filed before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 254 to 256 of 1963. A. S. Muhammad, for the appellant  in C.A.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 11, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C. J.

anchor.surface_text: March 11, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C. J.-Two

facts.text: K. Joseph Augusthi was the Managing Director of Palai Central Bank Limited from 26-1-1927 to 8-8-1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Joseph Augusthi was the Managing Director of the Palai Central Bank Limited from 26-1-1927 to 8-8-1960 George Thomas and George Joseph

facts.text: George Thomas was Director of Palai Central Bank from 14-1-1935 to 8-8-1960.

anchor.surface_text: George Thomas and George Joseph who are the appellants in the two other appeals Nos. 255 and 256 of 1963 respectively, were the Directors of the said Bank-, the first of them was the Director from 14-1-1935 to 8-8-1960

facts.text: George Joseph was Director of Palai Central Bank from 26-1-1927 to 8-8-1960.

anchor.surface_text: and the latter from 26-1-1927 to 8-8-1960. An application for the winding up of the said Bank was made before the Kerala High Court

facts.text: Reserve Bank made application for winding up of Palai Central Bank under section 38(3)(b)(iii) of the Act before Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: An application for the winding up of the said Bank was made before the Kerala High Court by the Reserve Bank under section 38 3  b  iii  of the Act. The said provision justi- fies the making of an application by the Reserve Bank

facts.text: On 8th August 1960, Official Liquidator appointed as Provisional Liquidator of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: On the 8th August, 1960, an order was passed on the said application appointing the Official Liquidator of the High Court the Provisional Liquidator of the Bank.

facts.text: Winding up order passed on 5th December 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The order of winding up then followed on the 5th December, 1960, and on the 8th December, 1960, an Official Liquidator was appointed under s. 39 of the Act.

facts.text: Official Liquidator appointed under s.39 on 8th December 1960.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 8th December, 1960, an Official Liquidator was appointed under s. 39 of the Act. After the Official Liquidator came on the scene, he made three reports

facts.text: Official Liquidator submitted report No.192 on 17th August 1961 under s.45G(1).

anchor.surface_text: After the Official Liquidator came on the scene, he made three reports to the High Court report No. 192 on the 17th August, 1961 report No. 242 on the 29th September, 1961

facts.text: Official Liquidator submitted report No.242 on 29th September 1961 under s.45G(1).

anchor.surface_text: report No. 242 on the 29th September, 1961 and report No. 350 on the 4th December 1961. All these reports were made under s. 45G 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Official Liquidator submitted report No.350 on 4th December 1961 under s.45G(1).

anchor.surface_text: and report No. 350 on the 4th December 1961. All these reports were made under s. 45G 1  of the Act. The appellants filed their objections

facts.text: Appellants filed objections to first two reports on 23rd November 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed their objections on the 23rd November, 1961 to the first two reports. The matter was then ,considered by the learned single Judge

facts.text: Kerala High Court single Judge ordered public examination of the three appellants under s.45G(2).

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then ,considered by the learned single Judge of the Kerala High Court and after hearing the parties, he made an order directing the public examination of the three appellants under s. 45G 2 .

facts.text: Division Bench of Kerala High Court dismissed appeals against single Judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the appellants by preferring three appeals before a Division Bench of the High Court. The Division Bench agreed with the view taken by the learned single Judge and dismissed the three appeals.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificates from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court and it is with the said certificates that they have companye to this Court by the present three appeals.

facts.text: Official Liquidator's reports stated that loss caused to bank by acts or omissions of directors and auditor.

anchor.surface_text: In his first report, the liquidator has stated that in carrying out the affairs of the bank, the Directors, with the help of officers appointed by them out of their own relatives, have number properly companyducted the affairs of the bank.

facts.text: Loans advanced by bank without adequate security or without any security.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the report that loans were advanced by the bank without regard to the question of any adequate security. In many cases, loans were advanced without any security at all

facts.text: Many debts became barred by time before winding up.

anchor.surface_text: and the inevitable companysequence has been that a large number of debts have become barred by time long before the winding up proceedings were started.

facts.text: Bank paid dividends without earning profits.

anchor.surface_text: The bank appears to have paid dividends without earning profits. Similarly, though it did number earn any profits between 1936 to 1958,

facts.text: Bank reported substantial net income without profits from 1936 to 1958 and paid income-tax thereon.

anchor.surface_text: it submitted reports showing substantial amounts as net income and so, it has paid income-tax on the said amounts. A large amount of advances appears to be irrecoverable.

facts.text: Directors appointed relatives as officers and did not properly conduct bank affairs.

anchor.surface_text: the Directors, with the help of officers appointed by them out of their own relatives, have number properly companyducted the affairs of the bank. He has also stated that in his opinion, loss had been caused

facts.text: Appellant Joseph Augusthi admitted bank treated accrued but unrealized interest as income for dividends and taxes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Joseph Augusthi companytended before the High Court that the bank used to treat interests accrued on advances, though number received, as income, and so, income-tax and super-tax were paid on such income and dividends were also paid on the same basis.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Liquidator's reports named 10 persons including three appellants as contributing to loss.

issues.text: Whether section 45G of the Banking Companies Act, 1949 is unconstitutional as it contravenes Article 20(3) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Both of them are related to section 45G of the Banking Companies Act, 1949  No. X of 1949   hereinafter called the Act . The first question raised has reference to the validity of the said section and the second to its true scope and effect. Dr. Seyid Muhammad contends that the answers given by the Kerala High Court to both these questions are erroneous According to him, s. 45 G is unconstitutional inasmuch as it contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed to the citizens of this country by Art. 20(3) of the Constitution.

issues.text: What is the true scope and effect of section 45G of the Banking Companies Act, 1949

arguments.claim: Section 45G does not contravene Art.20(3) as no person is accused of offence at public examination stage

anchor.surface_text: Article 20 3  provides that no person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself. ... Therefore, we do not think Dr. Seyid Muhammad is right in contending that s. 45G is invalid on the ground that it contravenes Art. 20 3  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Public examination under s.45G is investigative/preliminary, not accusatory; Art.20(3) inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: it may be conceded that when a person is compelled to submit to a public examination, that itself. prima facie, looks like pillorying him in the public gaze. ... The main object of Art. 20 3  is to give protection to an accused person not to be compelled to incriminate himself

arguments.claim: s.45G(1) covers any acts/omissions causing loss to bank, whether or not fraudulent

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the acts or omissions to which s. 45G 1  refers need not be fraudulent acts or omissions, because, in terms, the section provides that the act or omission would attract s. 45G 1  if it has led to any loss

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.45G(2) requires only prima facie consideration of report and explanation, not full trial

anchor.surface_text: What the Court has to do in exercising its power under s. 45G 2  is to consider the report made by the liquidator and decide whether it can reasonably entertain the opinion that any person ... should be publicly examined.

arguments.claim: Liquidator's reports disclose prima facie case of acts/omissions causing loss justifying public examination

anchor.surface_text: In his first report, the liquidator has stated that in carrying out the affairs of the bank, the Directors, with the help of officers appointed by them out of their own relatives, have not properly conducted the affairs of the bank.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry supports no violation of Art.20(3)

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may refer to a decision of this Court in Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry and Anr.  2 , where a somewhat similar provision contained in s. 240 of the old Companies Act

arguments.claim: Ex parte George Stapylton Barnes distinguished as requires fraud unlike s.45G

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this passage is hardly relevant for our purpose, because as we have already indicated, s. 45G 1  expressly provides that the act or omission complained of need not necessarily be fraudulent

arguments.claim: Sir Fazal Ibrahim Rahimtoola v. Appabhai distinguished; allegations here not vague

anchor.surface_text: The other decision on which Dr. Seyid Muhammad has relied is the judgment of the Bombay High Court in Sir Fazal Ibrahim Rahimtoola v. Appabhai C. Desai 2 . In that case, dealing with the provisions contained in s. 196

holdings.text: Section 45G of the Banking Companies Act, 1949 does not contravene Article 20(3) of the Constitution because at the stage of ordering public examination, no person is accused of any offence.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, unless it is shown that a person ordered to be publicly examined under s. 45G is, before, or at the time when the order for examining him publicly is passed, an accused person, Art. 20 3  will not apply. What then is the position with regard to a person against whom an order for public examination is made by the High Court as done against the appellants? All that has happened at the relevant time is that the official liquidator has submitted reports indicating that in his opinion, loss has been caused to the banking company under liquidation by the acts or omissions of the appellants, and the High Court, on consideration of the reports and taking into account the explanation ,given by the appellant, has come to the conclusion that, prima facie, a case has been made out for their public examination. In such a case, how can it be said that the appellants have been accused of any offence? ... Therefore, we do not think Dr. Seyid Muhammad is right in contending that s. 45G is invalid on the ground that it contravenes Art. 20 3  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public examination is investigative stage before any accusation; Art.20(3) applies only to accused persons; supported by precedents like Raja Narayanlal Bansilal.

holdings.text: Under section 45G(1), the acts or omissions need not be fraudulent or prohibited by law; any acts or omissions causing loss to the banking company suffice.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the acts or omissions to which s. 45G 1  refers need not be fraudulent acts or omissions, because, in terms, the section provides that the act or omission would attract s. 45G 1  if it has led to any loss to the banking company even though fraud may not have been committed by such act or omission. The context also shows that what the Court has to consider, is whether any act or omission on the part of the director or the auditor of the banking company has caused any loss to the company. Now, such an act or omission need not necessarily be criminal it may even include acts or omissions which are commercially unsound or unwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: section expressly includes non-fraudulent acts causing loss; contrasts with Companies Act s.478 requiring fraud.

holdings.text: The proviso to section 45G(2) is satisfied by prima facie consideration of the liquidator's report and the person's explanation at a preliminary stage, without a full trial on merits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso requires opportunity to show cause at prima facie stage; full enquiry would defeat purpose of preliminary investigation.

holdings.text: On the facts of the case, including the Official Liquidator's reports detailing acts and omissions causing loss (e.g., unsecured loans, barred debts, dividends without profits), a prima facie case exists for public examination of the appellants.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reports disclose specific acts/omissions causing loss; appellants' explanations (e.g., accounting practice) insufficient to rebut prima facie case; lower courts correctly applied test.

holdings.text: The true scope and effect of section 45G is a two-stage process: (1) liquidator reports on loss-causing acts/omissions; (2) High Court prima facie decides on public examination after show cause, leading potentially to disqualification under s.45G(9).

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it will be clear that the scheme of s. 45G is first to decide whether, prima facie, there is a, case for the public examination of a person then in deciding this question, give an opportunity to the person concerned if it is decided to hold a public examination of the said person, proceed to hold that examination if suggestions made against the person examined are found to be unwarranted, make an order of costs in his favour and if the person concerned is found to have been responsible for acts or omissions which caused loss to the banking company, to make a penal order disqualifying such person from acting as a director or an auditor as indicated by subsection  9 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme derived from reading subsections together; investigative, not accusatory; opportunity at preliminary stage.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; lower courts' orders affirmed on constitutionality, scope, procedure, and prima facie case.

anchor.surface_text: Sir Fazal Ibrahim Rahimtoola v. Appabhai C. Desai 2 . In that case, dealing with the provisions companytained in s. 196 of the old Companies Act, Chagla C.J. disapproved of the practice of ordering ex parte public examination of persons. In that companynection, he quoted with approval the warning sounded by Sir Lawrence Jenkins in the Ahmedabad Advance Spinning and Weaving Company v. Lakshmishanker 3 , that the practice of passing ex parte orders involving the person affected in serious liability is much to be deprecated.

The holding directly states that Section 45G does not contravene Article 20(3), resolving the constitutional issue raised.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, unless it is shown that a person ordered to be publicly examined under s. 45G is, before, or at the time when the order for examining him publicly is passed, an accused person, Art. 20 3  will not apply. What then is the position with regard to a person against whom an order for public examination is made by the High Court as done against the appellants? All that has happened at the relevant time is that the official liquidator has submitted reports indicating that in his opinion, loss has been caused to the banking company under liquidation by the acts or omissions of the appellants, and the High Court, on consideration of the reports and taking into account the explanation ,given by the appellant, has come to the conclusion that, prima facie, a case has been made out for their public examination. In such a case, how can it be said that the appellants have been accused of any offence? ... Therefore, we do not think Dr. Seyid Muhammad is right in contending that s. 45G is invalid on the ground that it contravenes Art. 20 3  of the Constitution.
The result is the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding directly resolves the issue by ruling that fraud or legal prohibition is not required under s.45G(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the acts or omissions to which s. 45G 1  refers need not be fraudulent acts or omissions, because, in terms, the section provides that the act or omission would attract s. 45G 1  if it has led to any loss to the banking company even though fraud may not have been committed by such act or omission. The context also shows that what the Court has to consider, is whether any act or omission on the part of the director or the auditor of the banking company has caused any loss to the company. Now, such an act or omission need not necessarily be criminal it may even include acts or omissions which are commercially unsound or unwise.
The result is the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it will be clear that the scheme of s. 45G is first to decide whether, prima facie, there is a, case for the public examination of a person then in deciding this question, give an opportunity to the person concerned if it is decided to hold a public examination of the said person, proceed to hold that examination if suggestions made against the person examined are found to be unwarranted, make an order of costs in his favour and if the person concerned is found to have been responsible for acts or omissions which caused loss to the banking company, to make a penal order disqualifying such person from acting as a director or an auditor as indicated by subsection  9 .
The result is the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
The result is the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
